text: Oris Johnson has warned that the fight

african-american losing his life for the

further public protest during the
pandemic and ward that some of those
involved in violence or causing damage
would face justice let's join our

we who lead and who gun simply can't

here there's plenty of evidence that the
UK's black population around 3% in the

gaps illustrated in a major official

black people are most likely to be in a

are out of work that's more than twice
the rate among a white community and
higher than 6% among Asians 39% of black

arrested in 2017 to 1810 white and 12
from the Asian community successive

does the Home Secretary recognize that
their structural inequality
discrimination and racism in our country
does the Home Secretary recognize that

Laura Coons Berg BBC News Westminster
now police in Bristol say they've

now yesterday police said that they were

people power or pure vandalism
justifiable or inexcusable edward
Colston's plinth now stands empty and
bristol is dealing with what happened
here for some the destruction of this
statue went too far Colston's name is
everywhere in Bristol and for decades
the city has struggled with his legacy
an MP who gave a fortune to local
charities but whose money came from the
brutal and deadly slave trade Cary
understands the conflict all too well
her granddad was a civil rights leader
in Bristol in the 1960s but she went to
a school built by Colston she wishes the
statue had been taken away peacefully by
politicians decades ago now she hopes
the city can move on looking at it empty
maybe it should remain empty maybe
that's one way of kind of bringing
everyone together to say that if we're
not all up standing up on that plinth
then no one should be up there so maybe
that's what should happen the sign

so yesterday some took matters into
their own hands
but even as the statue has being
disposed of Edward Colston continued to
divide as a political leaders my job to
understand all those those those
feelings and try and bring this bring
the city together you know in the face
of those crushing crushing
understandings Colston statue was thrown

to sail racing driver Lewis Hamilton
said on social media that it should be
left beneath the water like the bodies
of so many slaves who died but others
think it should be put on display I see
that now as a an artifact an historical
artifact I think it's part of Bristol's
history I think the damage that was done
to it is also part of its history on
Bristol's history and I think it belongs
in a museum where it can be useful as an
artifact in telling history tonight a
small number of locals turned up wanting
to pull the statue out of the water and
put it back on the plinth this city may
be redrawing its past the question now
is what that means for its future John
Kay BBC News Bristol well tens of
thousands of people took part in the
demonstrations over the weekend as part
of the black lives matter campaign
despite government warnings of the
health risks of being in a large group
during the pandemic many were determined
to take part in marches lots of them for
the first time our community affairs
correspondent Rihanna crossford has been
speaking to some of those who took to
the streets and asked what they wanted
to see happening next it's been two
weeks of taking to the streets two weeks
since the horrific death of George Floyd
unleashed a surge of feeling on our own
doorstep and it shouldn't happen to
anyone more or less it keep happening to
my people for some marching for the
first time this feels like a moment in
history I was kind of hesitant to do it
but you know as you grow older you start
to understand things a bit better and
you understand that if you man
to be part of the change now it can
benefit those people in future but the
protests have been criticized for a lack
of social distancing we can't just like
sit back and then just wait and let the
police keep you know killing black
people we can't let the brutality keep
going on can't let be you just go on for
several until it's convenient for us to
go back out there
therefore straighten their passion is
visible but till now that demand haven't

I seen a lot of you know big companies
coming out with posts like you know
black lives matter we we support the

nobody looks like me I go a bit you know

cleaning change it was easy to change

some action house they had your chance

won't stop till that happens we
Oxford BBC News Now with ministers you
as my colleague are Clive Clive Murray
who's been following these events since
George Floyd's killing two weeks ago
let's talk about the prime minister
statement tonight Clive he's talking
about understanding and recognizing
anger put that in context for us in
terms of what overall government
approach seems to be yeah because the
protesters frankly believed that the
government hue over the last few days
have focused too much on the Law & Order
side of things a tiny minority at the
end of the demonstrations on Saturday
who caused trouble and the protesters
believe that this is at yet another
attempt to divert from the main issue at
hand which is dealing with racial
inequality in this country it's an
attempt to change the subject Boris
Johnson speech I think tonight was an
attempt to dispel that notion and indeed
the Prime Minister talked about the cold
reality of injustice and discrimination
in education employment and the
application of the rule of law the
problem is where's the beef as that chap
in trionic Rockford's piece just said
you can't just talk you've got to walk
the walk and these protesters are seeing
Nancy Pelosi in Congress in the United
States
talk about putting forward a police
reform bill which would end police
chokehold and would have as mandatory
police racial bias training they're
looking at the police force in
Minneapolis being completely disbanded
and rebuilt mayor of New York Bill
DeBlasio talking about doing the same
thing for the world-famous New York
Police Department the NYPD and then of
course they look to people like Sadiq
Khan here in London who's talking about
a racial review of the major
institutions of the capital NHS local
government and the Met Police and all
these protesters are wondering well
where is the government's own proposals
for this what they want to see is a
cutting of that thread that direct line
from Edward Colston 300 years ago a
different form of racial bias and an
appalling behavior or that thread all
the way through to the racial problems
that we see in society today they want
that thread cut and they don't see any
proposals being put forth from the
government in order to do that live
again any thanks Claude Murray there
